SUNDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1949

The New York Times

Winner of Brooklyn Institute 1949 Award Prowess Ability as Pianist at Town Hall

By NOEL STRAUS

Remarkable gifts as musicians and technicians were made known by Lilian Kallir, 37-year-old pianist, who gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Looking even younger than her age, and blessed with a charming stage presence, Miss Kallir captivated her large audience with a series of performances so poised and controlled, so replete with insight and imagination, that she already presented well on the way toward an important career.

Born in Prague, of Austrian parents, Miss Kallir, who arrived in this country three years ago and is now an American citizen, won the 1949 American Artistic Award of the Cleveland Institute of Arts and Sciences. Her playing yesterday was completely self-effacing, since and wholeness. It was, moreover, unassuming, sensitive, poetic and completely refined. Miss Kallir knew how to shape a phrase, give her interpretation clear architectural design, and apply it to the masterly fashion.

Pushed Deeply Into Style

Even more to her credit was her ability to groble deeply into the meaning and style of her varied offerings and project the message of the music across the Technologies with the full measure of temperament and inborn feeling such artistry entails.

New York Journal-American

By Arthur Berger

Lilian Kallir, seventeen-year-old pianist, stirred a large audience to very enthusiastic applause at her New York debut recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Miss Kallir's listeners were prepared in advance for someone of more than ordinary talents, for, as winner of the 1949 American Artistic Award, she has the distinction of being included on the season's major series of the Brooklyn Academy of Music with top-flight artists. The confidence, efficiency, gestures of fingers, and acrobatic facility with which she dispatched her debut program yesterday afternoon were such that one could easily see how Miss Kallir would impress a board of experts judges. This was absolutely prize-winning playing—playing unperturbed by the indecisions and inhibiting of older pianists when self-consciousness sets in.

Lilian Kallir gave promise of great things in her Town Hall debut on Saturday. At 17 she disclosed an artistry quite exceptional for a ten-year-giant.

Her imaginative insight and her power to communicate feeling gave her performance as an air of distinction. She made it evident that she is worth hearing now.
